nodes.text: Conventional cost-benefit analysis presumes cost and benefit estimates are accurate and unbiased, but this assumption may be false and constitute a 'cost-benefit fallacy' that undermines resource allocation

Method: Built and analyzed the largest dataset of its kind with 2,062 public investment projects across eight investment types, 104 countries, covering 1927-2013; cost overrun measured as actual/estimated cost, benefit overrun measured as actual/estimated first-year benefits

Result: Cost estimates are highly inaccurate and biased; pooled average cost overrun ~1.39 (actual 39% higher than estimated), large skewness and extreme kurtosis (fat right tail); statistical tests reject accuracy and symmetry (p < 0.0001)

Result: Benefit estimates are inaccurate and biased toward overestimation; pooled average benefit overrun ~0.94 (6% shortfall weighted) with significant skewness and fat left tail; tests reject unbiased centered distribution (p < 0.001) though economic significance varies by type

Evidence: For most investment types cost overruns and benefit shortfalls coincide (e.g., rail cost overrun average 1.40 and benefit overrun 0.66); tests reject hypothesis that cost underestimation is balanced by benefit underestimation (p < 0.0001, Mann-Whitney)

Claim: Biases compound rather than cancel: investments are commonly harmed by both cost underestimates and benefit overestimates, causing benefit-cost ratios to be overestimated by roughly 50 to 200 percent depending on investment type

Claim / Conclusion: Systematic bias in cost-benefit analysis leads to misallocation of resources and can cause projects with negative net benefits to be approved, harming economies (documented cases include dams and mega-events)

Limitation: Data availability constraints and selection/survival bias exist (only 327 projects had both cost and benefit overruns; better-managed projects more likely to release data), so sample likely understates true cost overruns and overstates benefits

Explanation (behavioral): Root causes of systematic bias are behavioral (optimism bias, planning fallacy, overconfidence, and strategic misrepresentation) which lead planners to underestimate schedules, geology, price variation, scope changes and mitigation difficulty

Method / Remedy: De-biasing via the outside view and reference class forecasting (use empirical distribution of past estimation errors to adjust ex-ante forecasts) is proposed as the primary corrective method
Evidence: Reference class forecasting and outside-view de-biasing have been implemented at scale (examples: UK, Denmark) and independent evaluations report improved forecasting accuracy

Claim / Policy: Propose institutionally mandated reforms to mitigate the fallacy: (1) systematic de-biasing of forecasts, (2) introduce skin-in-the-game for forecasters, (3) require independent audits of forecasts, and (4) adapt cost-benefit practice to democratic, non-technical decision contexts

Rationale: Better methods alone are insufficient; improved incentives (accountability, litigation or penalties) and independent, politically insulated audits are needed to ensure forecasts are accurate and not politically distorted

Conclusion: Without acknowledging and correcting the cost-benefit fallacy, conventional ex-ante cost-benefit analysis is a misleading guide for public investment and must be reformed along behavioral, methodological, and institutional lines
